title: Spin representation
text:
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, the spin representations are particular <a href="projective%20representation">projective representation</a>s of the <a href="orthogonal%20group">orthogonal</a> or <a href="special%20orthogonal%20group">special orthogonal group</a>s in arbitrary <a href="dimension">dimension</a> and <a href="metric%20signature">signature</a> (i.e., including <a href="indefinite%20orthogonal%20group">indefinite orthogonal group</a>s). More precisely, they are <a href="representation%20of%20a%20Lie%20group">representations</a> of the <a href="spin%20group">spin group</a>s, which are <a href="Double%20covering%20group">double cover</a>s of the special orthogonal groups. They are usually studied over the <a href="real%20number">real</a> or <a href="complex%20number">complex number</a>s, but they can be defined over other <a href="field%20%28mathematics%29">field</a>s.
Elements of a spin representation are called <a href="spinor">spinor</a>s. They play an important role in the <a href="physics">physical</a> description of <a href="fermion">fermion</a>s such as the <a href="electron">electron</a>.
The spin representations may be constructed in several ways, but typically the construction involves (perhaps only implicitly) the choice of a maximal <a href="isotropic%20subspace">isotropic subspace</a> in the vector representation of the group. Over the real numbers, this usually requires using a complexification of the vector representation. For this reason, it is convenient to define the spin representations over the complex numbers first, and derive <a href="real%20representation">real representation</a>s by introducing <a href="real%20structure">real structure</a>s.
The properties of the spin representations depend, in a subtle way, on the dimension and signature of the orthogonal group. In particular, spin representations often admit <a href="Invariant%20%28mathematics%29">invariant</a> <a href="bilinear%20form">bilinear form</a>s, which can be used to <a href="Embedding">embed</a> the spin groups into <a href="classical%20Lie%20group">classical Lie group</a>s. In low dimensions, these embeddings are <a href="surjective">surjective</a> and determine special isomorphisms between the spin groups and more familiar Lie groups; this elucidates the properties of spinors in these dimensions.
Set-up.
Let be a <a href="dimension%20%28vector%20space%29">finite-dimensional</a> real or complex <a href="vector%20space">vector space</a> with a <a href="nondegenerate%20form">nondegenerate</a> <a href="quadratic%20form">quadratic form</a> . The (real or complex) <a href="linear%20map">linear map</a>s preserving form the <a href="orthogonal%20group">orthogonal group</a> . The <a href="identity%20component">identity component</a> of the group is called the special orthogonal group . (For real with an indefinite quadratic form, this terminology is not standard: the special orthogonal group is usually defined to be a subgroup with two components in this case.) Up to <a href="group%20isomorphism">group isomorphism</a>, has a unique <a href="connected%20space">connected</a> <a href="Double%20covering%20group">double cover</a>, the spin group . There is thus a <a href="group%20homomorphism">group homomorphism</a> whose <a href="kernel%20%28group%20theory%29">kernel</a> has two elements denoted , where is the <a href="identity%20element">identity element</a>. The spin representations are, in a sense, the simplest <a href="representation%20of%20a%20Lie%20group">representation</a>s of and that do not come from representations of and . A spin representation is, therefore, a real or complex vector space together with a group homomorphism from or to the <a href="general%20linear%20group">general linear group</a> such that the element is "not" in the kernel of .
If is such a representation, then according to the relation between Lie groups and Lie algebras, it induces a <a href="Lie%20algebra%20representation">Lie algebra representation</a>, i.e., a <a href="Lie%20algebra%20homomorphism">Lie algebra homomorphism</a> from or to the Lie algebra of <a href="linear%20map%23Endomorphisms%20and%20automorphisms">endomorphisms</a> of with the <a href="commutator%23Ring%20theory">commutator bracket</a>.
Spin representations can be analysed according to the following strategy: if is a real spin representation of , then its complexification is a complex spin representation of ; as a representation of , it therefore extends to a complex representation of . Proceeding in reverse, we therefore "first" construct complex spin representations of and , then restrict them to complex spin representations of and , then finally analyse possible reductions to real spin representations.

These may again be combined into an isomorphism "B": "S" → "S"∗.

Description and tables.
To complete the description of real representation, we must describe how these structures interact with the invariant bilinear forms. Since "n" = "p" + "q" ≅ "p" − "q" mod 2, there are two cases: the dimension and signature are both even, and the dimension and signature are both odd.
The odd case is simpler, there is only one complex spin representation "S", and hermitian structures do not occur. Apart from the trivial case "n" = 1, "S" is always even-dimensional, say dim "S" = 2"N".
